dk.statsbiblioteket.util.rpc
Class ConnectionManager<E>

java.lang.Object
  dk.statsbiblioteket.util.rpc.ConnectionManager<E>

public class ConnectionManager<E>
extends java.lang.Object

Helper class to maintain a collection of connections. Connections are created on request and are kept around for a predefined amount of time settable vi setLingerTime(int).

One of the core benefits of using this class is that it allows the Client to use stateless connections - ie not fail if the service crashes and and comes back up by "magical" means. Failure handling is provided free of charge.

Using a connection manager to manage RMI connections is simple. Assume we want to use a remote interface Pingable: 

 interface Pingable extends Remote {

     public String ping () throws RemoteException;

 }
If you export that interface over RMI you can connect to it like so: 
 // Basic set up
 ConnectionFactory<Pingable> cf = new RMIConnectionFactory<Pingable>();
 ConnectionManager<Pingable> cm = new ConnectionManager<Pingable>(cf);

 // When you need a connection do
 ConnectionContext<Pingable> ctx = cm.get("//localhost:2767/ping_service");
 Pingable server = ctx.getConnection();
 System.out.println ("Ping response: " + server.ping());
 ctx.unref()

Abstracting Out The RPC Implementation

Here follows how to abstract out the RMI dependency on the client side in the previous example.

Modify Pingable to be non-Remote and throw IOExceptions instead: 

 interface Pingable {

     public String ping () throws IOException;

 }
Now extend that interface with a remote interface: 
 interface RemotePingable extends Remote, Pingable {

     public String ping () throws RemoteException;

 }
Create a ConnectionFactory<Pingable> using a RMIConnectionFactory or something else underneath: 
 public class MyConnectionFactory extends ConnectionFactory<Pingable> {

     // This backend should be dynamically loaded from a configuration parameter
     ConnectionFactory<? extends Pingable> backend = new RMIConnectionFactory<RemotePingable>();

     public Pingable createConnection (String connectionId) {
         return backend.createConnection(connectionId);
     }
 }
With this in hand we can do 
 // Basic set up
 ConnectionFactory<Pingable> mycf = new MyConnectionFactory();
 ConnectionManager<Pingable> cm = new ConnectionManager<Pingable>(mycf);

 // When you need a connection do
 ConnectionContext<Pingable> ctx = cm.get("//localhost:2767/ping_service");
 Pingable server = ctx.getConnection();
 System.out.println ("Ping response: " + server.ping());
 ctx.unref()

getConnections

public java.util.Collection<ConnectionContext<E>> getConnections()
Get a Collection of all active ConnectionContexts

Returns:
a collection containing all currently cached connections

get

public ConnectionContext<E> get(java.lang.String connectionId)

Use this method to obtain a connection to the service with id connectionId. Make sure you call release(dk.statsbiblioteket.util.rpc.ConnectionContext) on the returned context when you are done using the connection.

Parameters:
connectionId - instance id of the service to get a connection for
Returns:
a connection to a service or null on error
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the manager has been closed
java.lang.NullPointerException - if connectionId is null

release

public void release(ConnectionContext ctx)

Any call to get(java.lang.String) should be followed by a matching call to this method. It is equivalent to remembering closing your file descriptors.

Equivalently you may call ConnectionContext.unref() instead of calling this method.

It is advised that consumers release their connections in a finally clause.

Parameters:
ctx - context to be released
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if ctx is null

reportError

public void reportError(ConnectionContext ctx,
                        java.lang.Throwable t)
Mark the connection as broken, and the manager will not reuse it.

Parameters:
ctx - connection which is broken
t - the cause of the error
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if ctx is null

reportError

public void reportError(ConnectionContext ctx,
                        java.lang.String msg)
Mark the connection as broken, and the manager will not reuse it.

Parameters:
ctx - connection which is broken
msg - a description of the error
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if ctx is null

checkError

public boolean checkError(ConnectionContext ctx,
                          java.lang.Throwable t)
Convenience method to check if a Throwable, or its immediate cause, is of a type that is associated with network errors. If it is ctx will be marked as errorneous by a call to reportError(dk.statsbiblioteket.util.rpc.ConnectionContext, java.lang.Throwable).

A common pattern would be:
 if (checkError(ctx, t)) {
     ctx = connManager.get (connId);
 }

Parameters:
ctx - the connection context in question
t - the throwable which type to check
Returns:
true if ctx has been marked as broken in which case the consumer should retrieve a new connection by calling get(java.lang.String).

close

public void close()

Close the manager for any further connections, and release all currently cached connections.

Calling get(java.lang.String) or setLingerTime(int) on a closed manager raises an IllegalStateException.

finalize

protected void finalize()
                 throws java.lang.Throwable
Overrides:
finalize in class java.lang.Object
Throws:
java.lang.Throwable
